On 08/11/2007, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Will,
>
>  One possibility is the junitext project, which maintains a 1.4
>  compatibility subproject.  I don't know whether they're caught up to
>  4.4.  Good luck,
>
>  David Saff
>
>
>  On Nov 8, 2007 1:01 PM, Will McQueen <willmcqueen@...> wrote:
>  > Hi James,
>  >
>  > I'm using JDK 1.4.2, and it seems that I don't have a choice to
>  > upgrade JDK because GWT relies on a JDK version <= 1.4.2. GWT
>  > translates Java to JavaScript, and the source files (or class files)
>  > must correpsond to JDK 1.4.2 or earlier. Given this, it seems that
>  > JUnit 4.x is compiled with JDK 5+. Is there a way I can re-compile
>  > JUnit 4.x (safely), and still be able to use it (and all its
>  > features, like Hamcrest) with JDK 1.4.2 (except for annotations...)?
>  >
>  > Regards,
>  > Will
>  >

I'm not sure what you mean about GWT - I use it on Java 5 and it works
fine. GWT 1.4 doesn't work with Java 5 features like generics though.
Have you tried compiling with a Java 5 JDK and seeing whether it works
for you?

Other options - I don't know how successful people have been using
retroweaver and similar tools in this situation.

I've used JMock , with the JUnit 3 integration when I was stuck on
Java 1.4. I think this included some Hamcrest functionality, but it's
quite verbose without Java 5 language features. You may be able to use
a subset of the full functionality in Hamcrest to do what you need?

Hopefully these suggestions will be of some use; sorry I can't be of more help.

Cheers,

James
